description:
In 1903, Guglielmo Marconi prepared to unveil his world-first,
long-distance wireless communication technology to the Royal
Institution in London. He was looking forward to roaring success,
scientific acclaim, and a string of wealthy new customers - but he
didn’t count upon falling victim to the first hack in history.

This is a tale of business secrets, flame wars, stage magic, and
magnificent sideburns, direct from the records of Edwardian England.

The talk highlights several of the lessons that the FLOSS and
information security communities can still learn from the fateful
events of 1903. Marconi’s tale is a master class in the necessity of
open source technology, as well as being a delightful introduction to
the art of vulnerability reporting.
title: Scientific hooliganism: what we can learn from the first hack in history
